tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
Decided to give Cantina a try last October, 8 months later results are finally out...

Tens of solo findings in 1st Java audit and outperforming top Cantina leaderboard bros by 3-7x feels pretty good, not gonna lie.

It's a shame the post-audit experience was so terrible I vowed never to return to that platform. *justified rant warning*

- 8 months resolution time, as of writing - bounty still not sent.
- Tens of hours spent escalating and defending submissions from wrong verdicts.
- Counted ~ 104 judging mistakes (wrong dupes, clear invalids, wrong severity) that have been corrected. More that haven't.
- Value loss of ~$110,000 due to resolution taking 7 months longer than it should and OP token tanking its way down to ~50 cents. 

Sure, when competing in non-USD contest pots fluctuations are an accepted risk. But 8 months of judges being incompetent and not being able to wrap up a contest was not part of my threat model. During the C4 judging days I would fully process 1000 findings in under a week (solo), OP-Java had 360 and multiple judges.

It comes as no surprise that Cantina never announced on socials the results unlike 5 other contests that completed this week, certainly couldn't be the case that they wanted to avoid bad press or highlighting TrustSec dominance, right?

It's a shame that we have to continue discussing bounty platform malpractices instead of critical bugs, but there is no other choice except keeping everyone accountable.  

A rant-free technical breakdown post for the solo finds will be coming shortly.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
4/4 - Security Lessons
Key takeaways for developers:

âŒ Never burn tokens directly from LP pools
âŒ Don't let trading actions manipulate pool reserves
âœ… Burn from user balances only
âœ… Audit complex tokenomics carefully
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
3/4 - Attack Flow
Attack breakdown:
1. Flash loan 23M USDT from PancakeV3
2. Buy FPC tokens â†’ price goes up
3. Sell FPC â†’ triggers LP burn â†’ price pumps more
4. Sell remaining FPC at inflated price
5. Repay flash loan + keep profits
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
2/4 - Vulnerability Details
When users sell FPC tokens, the contract burns tokens directly from the liquidity pool instead of the seller's balance!

This reduces LP token supply â†’ artificially inflates price â†’ creates arbitrage opportunity.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1/4 - Attack Overview
#FPC token on BSC suffered a $4.7M exploit due to a flawed burn mechanism!
The attacker used flash loans to manipulate token prices by exploiting the contract's faulty LP burning logic.

tweets.content:
4/4 Analysis
In the dWETH-105.mint() function, the authorization of the attacked contract in "Previous Transaction 2" is used to perform lending and profit making.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
3/4 Analysis
Call the Silo.boorow() function, record the debtToken(dWETH-105) in the hacked contract account, and lend WETH to Hacker.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
2/4 Analysis
The malicious parameters are parsed in the _fillQuote() function. The original function was designed to perform a swap operation, but the attacker constructed malicious parameters to make the hacked contract call the bWETH-105.borrow() function.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1/4 Analysis
The openLeveragePosition() function is called. The parameters passed in are customized by the attacker and are not checked. The value of flashloanTarget is AttackContract, so that the subsequent AttackContract can call back the onFlashLoan() function.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
Pre-transaction
The attacker first creates the attack contract AttackContract: etherscan.io/tx/0xbbedbc0c13â€¦
The hacked user approves the maximum loan amount to the LeverageUsingSiloFlashloanWithGeneralSwap contract: etherscan.io/tx/0x24a3ea7566â€¦
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
The root cause was that the hacked contract did not check the input parameters, allowing the attacker to pass in malicious parameters, steal the loan quota of the user who authorized the contract, and send the borrowed WETH to the attacker.

tweets.content: 4. Since the attacker has already created the [Bonding, LBM] pool, the pool address here is a non-zero address. Ultimately, the protocol adds liquidity to the pool at a very high ratio of the LBM price set by the attacker.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: 3. Calculate the address of the [Bonding, LBM] pool. The comment shows that the project party deliberately did not deploy the pool first, and waited until the repurchase mechanism was actually triggered before creating it, which gave the attacker an opportunity.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1. The main cause of this vulnerability is in the Bonding token. The attacker triggers the repurchase mechanism by purchasing a large number of Bonding tokens.
2. In the _finalizeSale() function, first exchange USDC for LBM
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: When the protocol added a large amount of LBM to the pool, the attacker exchanged the Bonding in his hand for USDC to make a profit.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: The root cause is that the pool used to add liquidity was not created in advance. The attacker first created a malicious [Bonding, LBM] pool with an unbalanced ratio. Then he used a large amount of USDC to buy Bonding to trigger the repurchase mechanism.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: When the accumulation of USDC in the Bonding contract exceeds a certain threshold, the repurchase mechanism will be triggered to convert USDC into LBM, and then liquidity will be added to the [Bonding, LBM] pool.

tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: 2/2. Neither the VaultRouter nor the Augustus contract checks the incoming swapData, allowing the attacker to manipulate the step of swapping USD0 to sUSDS in a malicious pool where all liquidity is added by the attacker and the price is unbalanced.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
Cause of the vulnerability
1/2. The VaultRouter contract can exchange USD0++ into USD0 at a ratio of 1:1, which is different from the market price of 1:1.02.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: The attacker then obtained all USD0 by removing liquidity. Finally, 1899838 USD0 was exchanged into 1943686 USD0++ through the USD0USD0++ market, with an exchange ratio of 1:1.02, and a profit of 43847 USD0++.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: In this #usual attack, the attacker first created a malicious [USD0, sUSDS] pool, and then used the privileged identity of the VaultRouter contract to exchange 1899838 USD0++ into USD0 at a ratio of 1:1, and exchanged USD0 into sUSDS in the malicious pool.

tweets.content:
Dexodus Hacked
1. The attacker uses the old price (low price) to open a position, and then closes the position with the current price (high price).
2. The Verifier price signature contains neither nonce nor deadline. So the attacker can replay the old price signature.

tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1. distributeA() is not verified. Its function is to repurchase and then send BNB to EXboy.
2. The hacker transfers token to the EXboy contract, triggering the sell function.
3. Since EXgirl sent a large amount of BNB to the EXboy contract, this sell can make more profit.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1. The hacker raises the value of purchasedAmount by repeatedly calling transferForm().
2. Then call transfer() once to trigger _distribute().
3. At this time, the value of purchasedAmount is increased.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
Then skim retrieves BUSD.
Then call transfer() to trigger the EXgirl repurchase and send the obtained BNB to the EXboy contract. Finally, transfer to the EXboy contract, trigger the sell function, and complete the profit.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: Flash loan BUSD and then exchange it for EXgirl. Then collect EXboy tokens from multiple addresses. Send BUSD to the EXgirl contract, and then repeatedly call its transferFrom() function: {from: pair, value: 0}
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
20240528 EXcommunity was hacked. This protocol includes two tokens: EXboy and EXgirl. The attacker took advantage of the flaws in the repurchase mechanism design to force investment and make profits.
tx: app.blocksec.com/explorer/txâ€¦
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: ç‰›é€¼
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: When a certain amount of NORMIE tokens are accumulated in the NORMIE contract, a repurchase will be triggered. It swap a large number of NORMIE tokens issued in the contract with ETH, causing the price of NORMIE in the pair to be abnormal, and the attacker will profit from it.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: In the `_transfer` function, it checks whether the amount of money received by `recipient` is equal to the balance of `teamWalletAddress`. If they are equal, `recipient` is set to the privileged account `premarket_user`. (This is really a weird design)
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: When the number of NORMIE tokens in the NORMIE contract accumulates to a certain level, a buyback will be triggered, and the tokens will be sent from the NORMIE contract to the pair in exchange for WETH. The attacker obtained a large number of cheaper NORMIE tokens.

tweets.content:

tweets.content: 20240526 NORMIE (meme token) was hacked. The attacker obtained the `premarket_user` rights, issued more tokens through multiple txs, and then triggered a buyback,, which eventually caused the additional tokens to flow into the pair, causing the asset value to depreciate.

tweets.content: I agree, I am also thinking about how to do these things.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content: Anyone can call the `convertAndBurn` function, which converts the specified token into PNT and then performs a burn operation. The attacker used this feature to perform a sandwich attack.
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
1. First, a large amount of PNT was swapped in
2. The `convertAndBurn` function was executed
3. The PNT swapped in (1) was sold to make a profit
tweets.author: ACai_sec

tweets.content:
20240522-Burner was hacked. The attacker performed a sandwich attack. Unlike the usual sandwich attack performed through MEV, this sandwich attack was performed in the same tx.
